alerts:monitors:create.description:
Create an Alert Monitor by attaching an Alert Trigger and a set of users and webhooks to an Instance.
While individual users and webhooks can be tied to alert monitors, it is recommended that you create alert groups and attach alert groups to alert monitors. This helps in the case that you need to add a user to a set of monitors: it's simpler to edit a single alert group than to edit dozens of alert monitors.

examples.description: Get the ID of an alert group named 'DevOps':
Get the ID of an instance named 'My Instance':
Get the ID of an execution duration trigger:
examples.command: TRIGGER_ID=$(prism alerts:triggers:list --columns id --filter 'name=^Execution Duration Matched or Exceeded$' --no-header)

examples.description: Create an alert monitor that alerts the DevOps group when an instance execution takes longer than 10 seconds:
examples.command: <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> --name "Alert Devops of slow execution" --instance ${INSTANCE_ID} --triggers "[\"${TRIGGER_ID}\"]" --duration 10 --groups "[\"${ALERT_GROUP_ID}\"]"

print-requests.description: Print all GraphQL requests that are issued
print-requests.name: print-requests

name.name: name

instance.name: instance

triggers.name: triggers

duration.name: duration

log-severity.name: log-severity

groups.name: groups

users.name: users

components:dev:run.description:
Fetch an integration's active connection and execute a CLI command with that connection's fields as an environment variable.
After specifying an integration ID and connection config variable name, this command executes a CLI command with that connection's fields saved as a config variable named PRISMATIC_CONNECTION_VALUE.

examples.description: To simply print an integration's basic auth config variable named "My Connection" and pipe the resulting JSON to jq, run:
examples.command: <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> --integrationId SW50ZWexample --connectionKey "My Connection" -- printenv PRISMATIC_CONNECTION_VALUE | jq

examples.description: If one of your integrations has an authenticated OAuth 2.0 config variable "Slack Connection", you could run your component's unit tests with that environment variable:
examples.command: <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -i SW50ZWexample -c "Slack Connection" -- yarn run test

examples.description: If you would like to fetch a connection from an instance deployed to one of your customers, specify the --instanceId flag instead
examples.command: <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> --instanceId SW50ZWexample -c "Slack Connection" -- yarn run test

print-requests.description: Print all GraphQL requests that are issued
print-requests.name: print-requests

connectionKey.description: Key of the connection config variable to fetch meta/state for
connectionKey.name: connectionKey

integrations:flows:listen.description: Listen for webhook executions on a flow and save the payload to a file

print-requests.description: Print all GraphQL requests that are issued
print-requests.name: print-requests

integration-id.description: ID of the integration containing the flow to listen to.
integration-id.name: integration-id

flow-id.description: ID of the flow to listen to. If not provided, you will be prompted to select.
flow-id.name: flow-id

flow-name.description: Name of the flow to listen to.
flow-name.name: flow-name

output.description: Output directory for the payload file. Defaults to ./payloads
output.name: output

timeout.description: Timeout in seconds to stop listening.
timeout.name: timeout

no-prompt.description: For flows using polling triggers, automatically poll without a confirmation prompt.
no-prompt.name: no-prompt

reset.description: Manually turn off listening mode for a given integration.
reset.name: reset

integrations:flows:test.description: Run a test execution of a flow

examples.description: Test an integration flow with a payload file and tail the logs and step results:

print-requests.description: Print all GraphQL requests that are issued
print-requests.name: print-requests

flow-id.description: ID of the flow to test. Base64 encoded.
flow-id.name: flow-id

flow-name.description: Name of the flow to test.
flow-name.name: flow-name

flow-url.description: URL of the flow to test. Prefer to use flow-id instead, if possible.
flow-url.name: flow-url

integration-id.description: ID of the integration containing the flow to test. Base64 encoded.
integration-id.name: integration-id

payload.description: Optional file containing a payload to run the flow with.
payload.name: payload

payload-content-type.description: Optional Content-Type for the test payload.
payload-content-type.name: payload-content-type

sync.description: Forces the flow to run synchronously.
sync.name: sync

tail-results.description: Tail step results from the test execution until user interrupt or timeout.
tail-results.name: tail-results

tail-logs.description: Tail logs from the test execution until user interrupt or timeout.
tail-logs.name: tail-logs

cni-auto-end.description: Automatically stop polling activity once an CNI flow execution completes. Some logs & results may not be returned this way. DOES NOT WORK FOR LOW-CODE FLOWS.
cni-auto-end.name: cni-auto-end

timeout.description: Optionally set a timeout (in seconds) to stop tail activity. Compatible with both low-code and CNI flows.
timeout.name: timeout

result-file.description: Optional file to append tailed execution result data to. Results are saved into JSON Lines.
result-file.name: result-file

jsonl.description: Optionally format the step and tail results output into JSON Lines.
jsonl.name: jsonl

debug.description: Enables debug mode on the test execution.
debug.name: debug

apiKey.description: Optional API key for flows with secured endpoints.
apiKey.name: apiKey

name.description: Name of the new integration to create (alphanumeric characters, hyphens, and underscores)
name.name: name

organization:signing-keys:generate.description:
Generate an embedded marketplace signing key.
The RSA public key is saved in Prismatic, and the private key is returned and immediately removed from Prismatic. Once the private key is returned, it cannot be retrieved again.

print-requests.description: Print all GraphQL requests that are issued
print-requests.name: print-requests

Import a RSA public key for use with embedded marketplace.
You can use openssl to generate a new RSA key pair and import the public key.

workflows:import.description: Import an embedded workflow or workflow template YAML definition

print-requests.description: Print all GraphQL requests that are issued
print-requests.name: print-requests

path.description: The path to the YAML definition of the workflow to import
path.name: path

workflow.description: The ID of the workflow being imported. If omitted, a new workflow will be created.
workflow.name: workflow

customer.description: The ID of the customer to associate with the imported workflow. This will overwrite the existing workflow. If omitted, the workflow will be imported as a template.
customer.name: customer

query.description: GraphQL query string (omit to read from stdin)
query.name: query

graphql:query.description: Execute an arbitrary GraphQL query against the Prismatic API

examples.description: Direct query string
examples.command: <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> 'query { customers { nodes { id name } } }'

examples.description: From file
From stdin
With variables
Variables from file
YAML output
examples.command: <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> 'query { customers { nodes { id name } } }' --output yaml

examples.description: Table output with nested data
examples.command: <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> 'query { customers { nodes { id name } } }' --output table --data-path customers.nodes --columns id,name

print-requests.description: Print all GraphQL requests that are issued
print-requests.name: print-requests

file.description: Treat query argument as file path
file.name: file

variables.description: JSON string or @file.json containing query variables
variables.name: variables

output.description: Output format
output.name: output

columns.description: Comma-separated field paths for table columns (required for table output)
columns.name: columns

data-path.description: Dot-notation path to array data in result (e.g., 'customers.nodes')
data-path.name: data-path
